author: Saumya Vaishampayan
title: Band Aid: Hong Kong’s Bill for Defending Its Peg Is $6.5 Billion and Counting
text:
0 COMMENTS HONG KONG—Hong Kong’s de facto central bank has spent about US$6.5 billion in the past week to defend its currency’s nearly 35-year-old link to the U.S. dollar .
The Hong Kong Monetary Authority said Thursday it has bought a total of 51.3 billion Hong Kong dollars and sold US$6.5 billion from its foreign currency reserves in 13 transactions since its first intervention last week.
“This is totally in accordance with the design of the linked exchange rate system,” said Howard Lee, deputy chief executive of the HKMA, adding that the amount and pace of the transactions have been consistent with the authority’s expectations.
A 500 Hong Kong dollar note. Photo: Reuters The HKMA allows the Hong Kong dollar to trade in a range of 7.75 to 7.85 to the U.S. dollar and says it will buy or sell U.S. dollars to maintain the local currency’s value.
“We see that the operation of the market has been smooth and orderly, and the market confidence in the ability of the HKMA to maintain [the] stability of the Hong Kong dollar is very strong,” Mr. Lee said at a briefing Thursday.
The Hong Kong dollar strengthened by as much as 0.08% against the U.S. dollar earlier, its biggest intraday rise in three months. One U.S. dollar bought 7.8481 Hong Kong dollars in recent trading, which meant Hong Kong’s currency was 0.02% stronger for the day.
Hong Kong’s dollar has been mostly depreciating against its U.S. counterpart since the beginning of last year, driven by a wide gap between U.S. and Hong Kong interest rates.
Local interbank rates have risen since the HKMA started intervening, but remain well below corresponding U.S. rates. That means it is still attractive for yield-seeking investors to swap Hong Kong dollars into U.S. dollars.
“Usually it will take some time for this sort of activity to die down,” said Tommy Wu, a senior economist at Oxford Economics in Hong Kong. He said he expects the Hong Kong dollar to continue hitting the weak end of its trading band over the next two to three months because the rise in local interest rates will be slow.
